setup.question: What gave Starre the right to claim the asteroid as her own when Parker and Queazy arrived?
answers: By common law, asteroids up to a certain size belong to whoever happens to be on them.
Her grandfather had purchased the asteroid for her.

Text.text: B seems simpler/more concrete
The story follows Bob Parker and Queazy who are trying to purchase an asteroid upon the request of
, who is in fact Starre's grandfather. When Parker and Queazy meet Starre, though, she explains that the reason she is staying on the asteroid is because

. She is claiming is so that her Grandfather's purchase of the asteroid--which is only attempted, not fulfilled--doesn't go through, because if it did, Starre would have to marry a man she does not love.
, she explains to Queazy and Parker. She does not really want the asteroid to be her "home" but is occupying it to thwart its purchase
I'm sure A will quote the line where A is stated, but right after (see line numbers), the speaker says she
.The companies in reference are those who purchase asteroids for clients. The main characters of this story refer to
as a
of their own company,
. The purchase order made by her grandfather trumps the common law asteroid decree, so B is the logical choice here.

Hmm both are compelling. It's currently unclear to me whether Starre's common law ownership trumps the (attempted?) purchase by her grandfather. 

B: it isn't obvious to me that just because her grandfather gave the order to multiple companies, that means that he actually successfully purchased it, considering the potential common law ownership that A described.

The idea of one ownership "trumping" another is completely made up and there is no evidence for this in the story. As you rightly inferred, judge, the grandfather has not successfully purchased the asteroid, hence why Starre believes--rightly so--that her being on the asteroid means it belongs to her. I'll restate the quote that contains the entirety of side A: "

. Both sides *attempting* to acquire the asteroid has no bearing on "what gave Starre the right to claim" it, as the question asks. What gave Starre the right was, again, common law, especially because Starre's interests are not at all aligned with those of her grandfather.
Starre's desires are not respected by her grandfather, but unfortunately, he is
, and as such he is able to circumvent his granddaughter's wishes. She even characterizes him as the
. He had purchased the asteroid for
. Starre even has plans to leave, saying
. She knows her grandfather's plan will come to fruition, and is merely prolonging her protest and marriage.

B: you didn't really respond to me or debater A, which makes me very sus. A has very clear evidence in favor of their answer, and B hasn't explained why the grandfather's attempted purchase actually trumps Starre's ownership. Him *eventually* winning out after the end of the passage b/c he's rich and powerful doesn't really say much about this question/debate.

As you said, Judge, B didn't respond to A's very clear argumentation explaining that the grandfather's theoretical and, again, unrealized purchase of the asteroid has any bearing on her "right to claim [it] as her own". 

I'll reiterate for a final time that there is quote in this story that very literally restates the entirety of side A:

. This is said by Starre in her explanation to Bob Parker and Queazy. Any arguments brought up by B that refer to the grandfather's wealth or how stubborn he is or how much he spent are obviously beside the point and are simply being used as futile distractions to convolute what should be an obvious judgement.

, and calls Starre out for it. She is pretending to abide by the common law when in reality, she is trying to put Bob and Queazy out of business, in cahoots with their rivals, the
who

and wanted to take the asteroid for themselves. Bob and Quezy must even resort to
to claim the asteroid, but in reality the grandfather and the granddaughter were in cahoots with their competition.

Ok given very concrete evidence for A, and without a *consistent* and coherent counterargument from B, I'm ending in favor of A. In particular, B's first argument that counters the *explicit* evidence for A should have been followed up on, if B was honest, and instead B presents basically three totally separate arguments, and doesn't tie them all together, which seems like solid evidence that answer B isn't correct.

A's quotes make way more sense for context, and also, B claimed that A would use a quote that they didn't. A has a clear quote showing how Asteriods of a certain size belong to whoever happens to be on them.
B has shown zero evidence that an attempted purchase can override common law

answers.reason for outcome: Evidence was there in the story, correct answer was pretty obvious.
A, because it was the factual answer.

This was a tricky one. B presented basically several totally separate arguments, which I would be very surprised if an honest debater did. Each argument was somewhat persuasive, especially their first one, but there wasn't a consistent narrative.
